title: How the Biggest Open Database of Companies was Built
segmentation: I've spoken a lot about company data in the last year or so.

Since we launched Opencorporates, I'm going to give a quick instruction, but I really thought it might be useful to talk about some of the how we did it, and some of the issues rather than just what we're doing.
Um?
We said well.
We set out to do opencorporates.
We had a simple, but a fairly big goal.
We wanted to create an open database and opening license database that had an entry and specifically a UI for every corporate legal entity in the world.
Every corporate legal entity in the world.
It's probably worth just mentioning what we mean by Corporal against E. Sometimes called a company that companies people think Microsoft is a company.
Microsoft isn't a company.
Microsoft is a collection of a network of hundreds thousands of different corporate legal entities and legal entity is quite important because that is the thing that has legal personality.
It's an artificial entity given legal personality by the state so that it can enter into contracts.
It can be sued, it consumes.
And so when it comes down to it, the people you work for, not Microsoft, but one of the legal entities within Microsoft, and so in all our lives.
The issue of what is the company is is critical, so we set out to in order to understand this.
In order to understand what companies are and what they look like, and corporations are, and for all sorts of other reasons, we set out to create a list of these identities, legal entities.
And create ur eyes as identifiers and the UI.
We decided that we wanted one without any where.
We had no embedded IP, either explicit IP or HIDDEN IP where we create a new identifier that that you had to go through us to in order to do it.
So we created a UI.

And there were also when we've got that data.
When we got that information, we can use that as a node as an entity to tie other things to it.
Other bits of public data to it.
That allows you to do something fairly powerful, which is to search for a company across multiple jurisdictions.
And more than more than that, when you get that information, it's all open licensed, under under a under the open database license, which means it's free to reuse even commercially.
So.
There are five core uses.
Why is this useful?
Why does it even matter?
What's the point?
When you got an open identa.

How do they pull it together and make sense of it?
Because in general they will hold it without really knowing what they're talking about, but if they know what?
If they say, OK, do you know what we're talking about?
BP Exploration Alaska Inc. And here's the UI for that.
Then it means they can combine their own data.
And it's not a.
It's not a sufficiency, but it is a requirement in terms of allowing different groups disparate groups to start sharing their own data.
So if we want to to have a wider understanding and be able to exchange each other data that we need to have identifiers that we can use.
Importantly, it can be used without reference to opencorporates.
You don't have to tell us you don't have to ask your permission, you can just go ahead and use those identifiers.

What's known as cool ur eyes because they map the ID.
Issued by the Company Register map to that.
Then if you know what the opencorporates ideas open corpus your eyes, you know what their company number is.

We didn't try to.
Solve all the problems.

Program that Phil mentioned yesterday in W3C for business for Capital E. Six months ago we were invited to be on the financial Stability Boards.
